and it's a classic French crust called Buckley's 
a and it's not the flaky pie crust it's got sort

of a tart cross shortbread II tenderness it's 
really good but most importantly you don't have

to worry about keeping things cold or overworking 
the dough it's really really simple so what I've

got here is some all-purpose flour and here's my 
little trick I'm gonna mix in a little bit of rice

flour and rice flour is completely gluten free 
so it reduces the total amount of gluten and it

prevents your crust from being tough makes it more 
tender a little bit of salt get that mixed up and

then right on to a work surface and I'm going to 
go in with my butter now this butter is actually

softened so it's been sitting at room temperature 
this is why I love this recipe before when I make

flaky pie crust it up freeze the butter and you 
know I'm in Thailand forget it it's always way

too hot I got to turn on the AC toss this in 
the flour and then I'm gonna rub it in with my

fingers until it's crumbly and there's no more big 
pieces all right so now that it's all crumbly like

this now I'm gonna make a well in the center again 
take liquid ingredients I've got an egg yolk right

here is gonna make the crust richer some water 
which I'm going to mix in and use my tiny little

whisk beefed-up together pour the liquid into the 
center and then use your finger to gradually stir

everything into the middle and then once it's 
becoming sort of thick like that gather all

your dry stuff and kneading it into the center 
so once it's sort of smooth we're gonna do a

technique that the French called phase ash you're 
basically taking this dough and you're using the

palm of your hand to smear it across the counter 
and that's to get rid of any big lumps of butter

that's still sitting in the dough see it's nice to 
be able to make a pie crust and not have to worry

about how many times you touch the dough because 
that's what flaky pie crust I'm always so paranoid

about oh my gosh I've touched the dough too much 
it's not gonna be good anymore and this dough is

the classic dough that's you for quiche as well so 
any sort of custard based pie or tart try to knead

together any sort of big cracks in the dough and 
now we're gonna let this chill in the fridge for

30 minutes the gluten needs to relax so the one 
we roll it out it doesn't try to it doesn't try

to shrink back it'll be a lot easier to work with 
so the dough has been chilling for 30 minutes now

try not to chill it for more than 30 minutes 
because what happens is it gets too hard the

butter hardens and then it's impossible to roll 
and then you gotta let it come to room temperature

again to soften it up so if you have to do it 
overnight that's fine but then you'll have to

pull it out ahead of time and let it come to 
temperature and soften so I've got that dough

now I'm just gonna roll it I'll show you a little 
trick it's what I learned in culinary school is

when you try to dust the table with flour instead 
of sprinkling it when you get big clumps just kind

of throw it it becomes a lot more even like that 
and it's so much fun there you go throw it on top

and now roll it to about an eighth of an inch 
thick to prevent the edges from cracking too

much the edges are gonna crack a little bit as you 
roll don't try to push it down really hard all at

once slowly and gently and the cracks will be very 
small and it's more easily patched towards the end

and as I go I like to just patch the the crack 
up a little bit just so keep it under control

I'm gonna transfer that onto my pie plate so you 
kind of got to do this gently the good news is

that it also patches back much more easily than 
flaky pie dough so if you break it it's okay you

just need it back together and no one will know 
lift it up and then you place it back down oh

it's so exciting okay so now it's important that 
it rests right up against the pie plate so lift

and push till you feel it really come up against 
the edge now I'm just gonna trim off the edges

right up against the pie plate clean this up a 
little bit pressing it together so it's smooth

it doesn't have to be perfect rusticity is a 
trendy thing these days and now to decorate it

I like to just use a fork and just press along 
the edges to create a design a really simple

design you don't need to crimp it do anything 
crazy okay and now I'm just going to dock the

bottom of the pie if there's any air bubbles 
it'll allow them to escape through these holes

and so you won't get big bumps and lumps in your 
pie that's good now I'm gonna let this rest in

the fridge for ten more minutes and we want to 
do that because we've just worked the gluten in

the dough if we bake it right now the gluten is 
very tight and elastic and it likes to shrink if

we let it rest it won't shrink as much okay so 
let the sit in the fridge see ya ten all right

we're ready to bake the pie but you want to par 
bake the crust first and we're gonna blind bake

it and what that means is we're gonna bake it 
with some pie weight on top so I've got here

a piece of parchment paper and what I'm gonna do 
is here's again my trick wrinkled it up because I

find that when it's wrinkled it conforms better 
to the shape when it's straight it's all stiff

I'm gonna put some pie weight which in my case is 
rice because you can probably guess that I have

an abundance of rice at my house but you can do 
beans you can do these actually sell pie awaits

but anything that is heat resistant heavy enough 
just go around and make sure that it sort of right

up against the edge and this will prevent the pie 
from shrinking as it bakes gonna bake this in a

350 degree oven for 20 minutes you want to make 
sure this gets baked on the very bottom shelf

to move your rack all the way to the bottom 
now I'm gonna pull out the pie wait ever so

carefully the worst thing to happen is have the 
rice filling everywhere let it hang out there and

so by the way you can reuse this as many times 
as you want I have no idea how many times I've

used them I just keep using them over and over 
and over again now I'm gonna put this pie back

in and as you can see it's still a little moist 
in the middle so we want to take out the rice

and let it bake for 5 more minutes to let the 
bottom sort of dry up and then the crust will

be perfectly blind baked so I'll tell you what 
I do with these scraps is you're gonna mean you

could throw it out but what I like to do is I 
try to patch them back together and then I roll

it just to get it kind of smooth and then what I 
do is I cut them into just small pieces and I bake

this up and then they become sort of like little 
crackers and I just eat it with cheese with the

spread or whatever I mean it's better than just 
wasting them right they're perfectly good they

just don't look very good but I just have sort of 
a ziploc bag of these and I eat them with cheese
